content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays two large, well-circumscribed pieces of tissue that have the characteristic architecture of lymph nodes. They are stained with H&E, showing dense purple lymphoid tissue. The overall impression is of reactive-appearing lymph nodes, but in the context of colorectal cancer, a meticulous search for metastatic tumor deposits is required.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

I am zooming into this area because it is located in the periphery of the left-most lymph node, specifically in the subcapsular region. Metastatic cancer cells typically travel via lymphatic channels and first implant in the subcapsular sinus. Therefore, systematically examining the entire subcapsular sinus of each lymph node is the standard and most effective method for detecting early metastases. This represents the beginning of a systematic review of this lymph node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it is located in the sinus region of the lymph node on the left. Metastatic carcinoma cells arriving via afferent lymphatics typically first deposit in the subcapsular and medullary sinuses. This is therefore a critical and high-yield area to examine for the earliest evidence of metastasis. Any subtle architectural change or presence of atypical, non-lymphoid cells in this location is highly suspicious and requires high-power examination. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because it is located in the perinodal fibrofatty tissue between the two main lymph nodes. This is a critical area to inspect for several reasons: 
1. To search for lymphovascular invasion (LVI), which involves tumor cells within the lumen of blood or lymphatic vessels. The area highlighted contains a distinct, circular, eosinophilic structure that is clearly a blood vessel. 
2. To look for extranodal extension of tumor from an involved node.
3. To identify discrete tumor deposits (TDs), which are separate nodules of cancer in the soft tissue that are prognostically important. 
Therefore, examining the vessels and soft tissue between nodes is a crucial step in accurate cancer staging. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the second lymph node from the left to begin a systematic high-power examination. My standard practice is to scan the entire lymph node, and this represents one of the initial fields of view. I need to assess the cellular composition and architecture in detail to look for signs of metastasis, such as nests of atypical epithelial cells, abnormal glandular structures, or effacement of the normal lymph node sinuses by tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. The zoom is focused on the periphery of the lymph node on the right, specifically targeting the subcapsular sinus region. This is the most important area to scrutinize for metastasis, as cancer cells arriving through lymphatic channels typically first implant and grow in the subcapsular sinus. This area might have appeared subtly different in color or texture at lower power, warranting a high-magnification view to rule out or confirm the presence of small tumor cell clusters (micrometastasis). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am beginning my systematic examination of the lymph nodes to screen for metastasis. The green box is placed over the first lymph node (the one on the left). This area is in the cortex of the node, a common location to start the assessment, allowing me to evaluate the subcapsular sinus and the lymphoid follicles for any atypical cell infiltrates. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area because it is at the periphery of the first (left) lymph node, likely in the subcapsular sinus region. This is the most common location for initial metastatic deposits to arrive and begin to grow. Additionally, this area appears subtly different in color and texture on the low-power view, being slightly paler and more mottled, which raises suspicion for infiltration by tumor cells amidst the normal lymphoid tissue. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the lymph node parenchyma with preserved architecture. The tissue is composed of dense lymphocytes organized into follicles. The subcapsular sinus (the space just beneath the capsule, visible at the top) contains some scattered histiocytes (sinus histiocytosis), which is a benign reactive finding. There are no definitive clusters of atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or other features to suggest metastatic carcinoma in this specific field. My impression is that this particular area is benign and reactive.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the architecture of a lymph node with lymphoid follicles and expanded sinuses. The sinuses are filled with a population of cells, including many histiocytes (larger cells with more abundant pink cytoplasm), a finding known as sinus histiocytosis. This is a reactive change. I do not see definitive nests of malignant epithelial cells or glandular formation to confirm a diagnosis of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The prominent black curved line is an artifact (likely ink from marking the slide). My impression is of a reactive lymph node, but I would continue to search carefully for isolated tumor cells, as sinus histiocytosis can sometimes be seen in nodes draining a tumor.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows several key features. At the bottom right, there is a cross-section of a thick-walled artery with a muscular media, typical of a vessel in the perinodal fat. The lumen is clear of any tumor cells. At the top left, there is the periphery of a lymph node, composed of a dense sheet of small, dark lymphocytes. Between the artery and the lymph node, there is fibroconnective tissue containing some small aggregates of lymphocytes. There are no atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or desmoplasia to suggest metastatic carcinoma. My impression of this specific area is that it is benign, showing a normal artery and perinodal lymphoid tissue with no evidence of lymphovascular invasion or a tumor deposit.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a dense population of lymphocytes. There are multiple, well-defined, and variably-sized lymphoid follicles, some with pale-staining germinal centers. This architecture is characteristic of reactive follicular hyperplasia, a benign condition where the lymph node is reacting to inflammation or infection. I do not see any definite nests of malignant cells or glandular structures typical of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma in this specific field. My impression for this area is a benign reactive change, but I must continue to scan the entire lymph node to rule out a small metastatic focus elsewhere.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, there are distinct clusters of atypical cells located within the subcapsular sinus. These cells are much larger than the surrounding small, dark lymphocytes. They have abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm and large, irregular, and dark nuclei. Some of these cells appear to be forming poorly defined glandular structures. This finding is diagnostic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing a metastatic deposit from the primary colorectal cancer.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see the preserved architecture of a lymph node. There are multiple lymphoid follicles, some of which appear atrophic or have inconspicuous germinal centers. These follicles are surrounded by a dense population of small, mature-appearing lymphocytes in the paracortex. I do not see any nests, clusters, or glands of atypical epithelial cells that would suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field is that it represents benign lymphoid tissue, likely showing reactive or involutional changes. I would proceed to scan the remainder of this node and the second node to completely rule out metastasis.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I can clearly see sheets of normal small, dark lymphocytes. However, infiltrating this lymphoid parenchyma are distinct clusters and nests of atypical epithelial cells. These cells are large, have abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and pleomorphic nuclei with irregular contours. They are forming back-to-back glandular structures. This is a classic appearance of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
